snippet: Officials have repeatedly backtracked since lifting a tap-water ban after a chemical spill last month, and residents are expressing growing distrust of health authorities’ reassurances.
abstract: Toxic chemical spill in West Virginia has spiraled into a crisis of confidence in state and federal authorities, as residents complain of confusing messages and a lack of trust in experts; spill continues to arouse fear and outrage and threatens a political crisis in a state where lawmakers have long supported the coal and chemical industries.

byline.contributor: Daniel Heyman contributed reporting from Charleston, W.Va.

lead_paragraph: Officials have repeatedly backtracked since lifting a tap-water ban after a chemical spill last month, and residents are expressing growing distrust of health authorities’ reassurances.

headline.main: One Month After Toxic Spill, West Virginians Face ‘Crisis of Confidence’
headline.print_headline: One Month After Toxic Spill, West Virginians Face ‘Crisis of Confidence’
